Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Routine Maintenance of Registration Lists

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Databases that contain information about people need regular attention to keep them up-to-date as individuals move, die, become inactive, or otherwise change status. The refreshing of state and local registration lists must therefore take place periodically to prevent the integrity and usefulness of the data from degrading. Across the United States, though, the particular practices used to maintain registration lists vary with local conditions and traditions. The effects of data-updating choices implemented during the pandemic are particularly hard to understand. This project therefore investigates the relationship between demographic data and registration list updates. Variables of sociological interest in this context include the procedures used, the officials responsible for the process, the socio-demographic characteristics of communities, and the regional effects of Covid-19. To test hypotheses about these variables, the project compiles an open database of list maintenance procedures that can serve as a public resource. This can help scholars, data scientists, and decision-makers better understand the menu of alternatives available to protect the accessibility, accuracy, and security of such lists.

Across all 50 U.S. states, the project will match data about registration lists, the demographics of individuals, the socioeconomic characteristics of their communities and officials, list maintenance procedures, as well as COVID-19 disruptions and responses. The study will use longitudinal, multilevel, and spatial analysis to test hypotheses about different ways of performing maintenance on registration lists. This project is jointly funded by the Sociology Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The the team completed a number of key outcomes related to the award grant. In particular, we have accomplished the following:

1. Colleted, cleaned, and began our construction of a database of Local Election Officials. This database is essential in understanding the maintenance of voter registrations, whether LEOs were elected or appointed to the position, and their length of time serving as an LEO.

2. We have cleaned the voter registration data (from 2016 through 2021), constructed new measures of race/ethnicity corresponding with each voter in the rolls, and began analyses for three manuscripts:

  • Assessment of polling place location and relationship with voting propensity. Preimilary research was presented at the 'Election Science, Reform, & Administration Conference."
  • A manuscript assessing the spatial variation in voting population which is comparing the American Community Survey and State Voter Roll data. Preliminary research will be presented at the North American Meetings of the Regional Science Association International conference.
  • A manuscript looking at voter roll transistions and the unequal consequences of roll maintenance. Results from this paper have been presented at the NDSU Social Science Colloquium and used as a demonstration of big data analyses for the NDSU Summer Institute in Computational Social Science.

3. We also trained and mentored four graduate students in data management and analyses techniques. These include training the best practices of data cleaning, exploratory data analyses, and interpreting research results. Further, this project provided opportunities for undergraduate research assistants to gain experience in data collection, cleaning, and key research processes.

Modified by: Dane R Mataic

Colleted, cleaned, and began our construction of a database of Local Election Officials. This database is essential in understanding the maintenance of voter registrations, whether LEOs were elected or appointed to the position, and their length of time serving as an LEO. 2. We have cleaned the voter registration data (from 2016 through 2021), constructed new measures of race/ethnicity corresponding with each voter in the rolls, and began analyses for three manuscripts: Assessment of polling place location and relationship with voting propensity. Preimilary research was presented at the 'Election Science, Reform, & Administration Conference." A manuscript assessing the spatial variation in voting population which is comparing the American Community Survey and State Voter Roll data. Preliminary research will be presented at the North American Meetings of the Regional Science Association International conference. A manuscript looking at voter roll transistions and the unequal consequences of roll maintenance. Results from this paper have been presented at the NDSU Social Science Colloquium and used as a demonstration of big data analyses for the NDSU Summer Institute in Computational Social Science. 3. We also trained and mentored four graduate students in data management and analyses techniques. These include training the best practices of data cleaning, exploratory data analyses, and interpreting research results. Further, this project provided opportunities for undergraduate research assistants to gain experience in data collection, cleaning, and key research processes.
